citeinfo.title: Oregon Spotted Frog (Rana pretiosa) Monitoring at Jack Creek 2015
citeinfo.geoform: Microsoft Access Database exported as separate comma-delimited files

descript.abstract: This dataset contains information from mark-recapture surveys conducted in 2015 by USGS as part of an ongoing Oregon spotted frog (Rana pretiosa) monitoring effort at Jack Creek, Klamath County, Oregon. Data consist of spotted frog counts aggregated by date, location, life stage, and sex, as well data on environmental conditions at the time each survey.
descript.purpose: This site is part of ongoing studies of Oregon spotted frog habitat use and population dynamics throughout its Pacific Northwest range. The results of this study will contribute to our understanding of the biology of this sensitive species and have implications for improved management efforts.

spdom.descgeog: Jack Creek, Williamson River watershed in Klamath County, Oregon

citeinfo.origin: Crother, Brian I., Jeff Boundy, Jonathan A. Campbell, Kevin De Queiroz, Darrel R. Frost, Richard Highton, John B. Iverson, Peter A. Meylan, Tod W. Reeder, Michael E. Seidel, Jack W. Sites Jr., Travis W. Taggart, Stephen G.Tilley, and David B.Wake

citeinfo.title: Amphibians of the Pacific Northwest
citeinfo.geoform: Microsoft Access Database exported as separate comma-delimited files

taxonsys.taxoncom: After being trained on proper species identification in the field, crew members used a variety of resources to ensure species identifications were robust. If an animal could not be positively identified during a survey, it was captured with a dip-net and examined closely. If any uncertainty remained, the observer referred to a field guide and/or took photos of the animal to be reviewed by an expert. Oregon spotted frogs are easily distinguishable from most other amphibian species in our study area. Thus, we are confident in the accuracy of our identifications.

taxonomy.taxongen: All amphibians were identified to the level of species in the data

cntperp.cntorg: U.S. Geological Survey Forest and Rangeland Ecosystem Science Center

idinfo.datacred: U.S. Forest Service, U.S. Geological Survey seasonal technicians, landowners

attracc.attraccr: Field data were collected on paper and reviewed (QA/QC) in the field for accuracy and completeness by one member of the crew (not the data recorder) at the end of each survey. Those data were entered into a Microsoft Access database and reviewed by a different individual to confirm that the data had been entered correctly. Once all data were entered and checked for completeness and accuracy, a random 10% subsample of that year’s surveys were once again screened for errors.

dataqual.logic: Data were checked for logical consistency by writing grouping queries to examine the proper spelling and standardization of all text fields. Range queries were written to confirm that numerical values were not outside a reasonable range for a particular field. We performed outlier checks by plotting numerical values bounded within a range (e.g., elevation, temperature, frog snout-urostyle length, frog mass). Bounding dates were confirmed as correct. Site coordinates were reviewed with Maptech, ArcMap, or other mapping software.
dataqual.complete: Data set is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.

horizpa.horizpar: GPS data were downloaded from the device at the end of the field week. Spatial data were projected on an ArcMap layer to ensure positional accuracy.

vertacc.vertaccr: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted.

method.methdesc: Oregon spotted frog breeding surveys were conducted on March 26, April 8, and April 9 of 2015. During each site visit, surveyors counted Oregon spotted frog egg masses (keeping track of old and new masses) and quantified oviposition site variables. Mark-recapture surveys were completed over three days from Sept 1 to Sept 3, 2015. At each pond/site, crew members worked in pairs or individually to search for Oregon spotted frogs in all suitable microhabitats. Upon entering a site, researchers sanitized hands with 70% alcohol-based sanitizer and allowed it to dry before rinsing hands in site water. Hands were sanitized between the handling of individual frogs. During each site visit, sub-adult and adult frogs (> 40 mm SUL) were caught, scanned for a PIT tag, given a new tag if necessary, and released at the point of capture. Every effort was made to complete the process efficiently with minimal disturbance to the frog. A sterilized PIT tag was inserted into the dorsum of a suitably-sized frog only after researchers confirmed (by scanning with a tag reader and visual inspection) that the frog did not have an existing tag. Once inserted, the PIT tag was manipulated into proper position under the skin just above the urostyle. If it was necessary to hold animals in queue for processing, each individual was placed in a separate zip-closure plastic bag filled with site water and vegetation. Animals were held in shaded areas and for no longer than 15 minutes. When a frog was captured, it was processed efficiently and released as to reduce disturbance to the frog.

procstep.procdesc: Data from datasheets were entered into respective project databases.
Data were checked for omissions and logical consistency following QA/QC protocol.

Frog counts were aggregated by survey date, location, life stage, and sex using script in R statistical analysis software. Data were exported as a comma-separated file and formatted into final Observations spreadsheet.

enttyp.enttypd: Spreadsheet contains information on observations (counts) of Oregon spotted frogs at sites within the Jack Creek study area, aggregated by date, location, life stage, and sex.

attrdomv.udom: Unbounded list of unique site names

attr.attrdef: Number of Oregon spotted frogs observed. For egg masses, this number is # of egg masses detected on that date that were not detected previously. For all other life stages, it is the total number observed on that date.
Life stage observed; eggmass, juvenile, subadult, or adult

edom.edomvd: Oregon spotted frog discrete cluster of embryos (eggmass)
Oregon spotted frog juvenile; animal has taken adult form (possibly still has tail stump), but is small and not sexually mature
Oregon spotted frog subadult; animal is older than one year, but is not sexually mature
Oregon spotted frog adult; animal has fully taken adult form and is sexually mature. Typically greater than 40 mm snout-urostyle length.

attr.attrdef: Township location for the observation, according to Public Land Survey System (PLSS)
Range location for the observation, according to Public Land Survey System (PLSS)
Section location for the observation, according to Public Land Survey System (PLSS)

enttyp.enttypd: Spreadsheet containing data on date and time of surveys, observers, environmental conditions, and notes for each survey.

attrdomv.udom: Unbounded list of unique site names

attr.attrdef: Number of observers participating in survey

attrdomv.udom: Unbounded number of observers conducting survey

attr.attrdef: Weather conditions at start of survey

edom.edomvd: Sky completely clear of cloud cover

attr.attrdef: Wind conditions at start of survey

edom.edomvd: Water surface smooth, smoke rises vertically
Small ripples in water, leaves rustle

attr.attrdef: Air temperature at start of survey
Units of air temperature measurements; Fahrenheit or Celsius

distinfo.distliab: Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the accuracy or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from a U.S. Geological Survey server, and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata file associated with these data. The U.S. Geological Survey shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.
